Solvent and co-catalyst dependent pyrazolylpyridinamine and pyrazolylpyrroleamine nickel(II) catalyzed oligomerization and polymerization of ethylene Collins Obuah a Bernard Omondi a Kyoko Nozaki b James Darkwa a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Johannesburg, Auckland Park Kingsway Campus, Auckland Park 2006, South Africa Department of Chemistry, University of Johannesburg Auckland Park Kingsway Campus Auckland Park 2006 South Africa b Department of Chemistry and Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku 113-8656, Japan Department of Chemistry and Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Tokyo 7-3-1 Hongo Bunkyo-ku 113-8656 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Four new nickel catalysts have been used to catalyze the oligomerization and polymerization of ethylene, leading to solvent and co-catalyst dependent products. The pyrazolylamine ligands, 2-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethan-amine (L1a), 2-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethan-amine (L2a), 2-(3,5-dimethyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl-(1H-pyrrol-2-ylmethyl)-amine (L3a), 2-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl-(1H-pyrrol-2-ylmethyl)-amine (L4a), were prepared by reducing the corresponding imine compounds L1–L4. L1a–L4a were then reacted with [NiBr2(DME)] to form the nickel complexes, [NiBr2(L1a)] (1), [NiBr2(L2a)] (2), [NiBr2(L3a)] (3) and [NiBr2(L4a)] (4) in high yields. When activated with aluminum co-catalysts, all four nickel complexes were able to catalyze the oligomerization or polymerization of ethylene; but the products of these reactions were co-catalyst and solvent dependent. With EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst and in toluene, butene and hexene were formed, which subsequently alkylated the solvent selectively to butyl-, dibutyl- and tri-butyltoluene. The same catalysts in chlorobenzene produced butene, hexene and highly branched polyethylene. Changing the co-catalysts to MAO and with toluene as solvent, complexes 2 and 3 catalyzed the polymerization of ethylene to high molecular weight (447,300Da) linear high density polyethylene (ca T m =135.5°C); with polydispersity indices ranging from 1.63 to 2.51. Keywords Ethylene Al co-catalyst Oligomerization Friedel–Crafts Polymerization 1 Introduction Late transition metal complexes have served as pre-catalysts for a number of reactions, including oligomerization and polymerization of ethylene during the last decade [1,2]. Single-site metal catalysts are now the preferred choice in most of these catalytic processes [3]. As a result, highly active catalyst systems containing well-defined active centers and structures for olefin polymerization have been discovered; resulting in well-defined polymer properties [4]. One of the most studied late transition metal for single-site ethylene oligomerization and polymerization catalysis is nickel. These nickel catalysts have bidentate or tridentate ligands with various combinations of σ-donor atoms such as N, P, O and S [5]. Nickel usually forms four-coordinate complexes with these ligand systems. Examples of these are bis(oxazolin-2-ylmethyl)phosphonite nickel catalysts, reported by Braunstein and co-workers [6], which oligomerize ethylene to mainly 1-butene. However, there are a few five-coordinate nickel compounds reported in literature [7]. The seminal work by Brookhart [8] and Gibson [9] on the use of α-diimine ligands in preparing α-olefin transformation catalysts has resulted in numerous nitrogen ligand supported catalysts for polymerization of ethylene [10], asymmetric catalysis and various CC transformation reactions [11]. The popularity of α-diimines, and indeed Schiff base ligands in general, stems from their ease of synthesis, their ability to stabilize metals in different oxidation states and the ease with which the electronic and steric properties of the resulting catalysts can be modified [12]. Despite the advantages offered by Schiff base metal complexes, the propensity of the imine group to hydrolyze remains a major drawback. Chattopadhyay and co-workers [13], reported that nickel(II) ions can hydrolyze the imine group back to the amine from which the imine functional group in the Schiff base ligand came. This phenomenon has also been observed by Darkwa and co-workers recently [14]. Other nitrogen-donor ligands, such as pyrazole and its derivatives, constitute another important group of nitrogen-donor compounds that have been used in making olefin transformation catalysts [15] due to their attractive coordination chemistry. Pyrazoles in mixed-nitrogen donor ligands are also attracting attention since they were first introduced as supports for catalysts in ethylene oligomerization and polymerization reactions by Jordan in 1999 [16]. Further work by Darkwa and co-workers with nickel(II) and palladium(II) pyrazole complexes [17,18] or mixed-nitrogen donor ligands containing pyrazole [19,20], have shown they are good catalysts for the oligomerization and polymerization of ethylene. Recently, however, there have been reports on nickel catalysts which oligomerize ethylene followed by Friedel–Crafts alkylation of toluene by the ethylene oligomers formed in the oligomerization reaction [19,21]. Two of these reports have been by Dyer et al. [21a] and Song et al. [21b] The Dyer catalyst system [21a] uses EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst, in a Ni:Al ratio of 1:14; first producing butene and hexene before these olefins alkylate toluene that was used as solvent for the reaction. The report by Song et al. [21b] on the other hand, uses MAO as co-catalyst to produce the active catalyst that oligomerizes ethylene to butene, hexene and octene before the olefins produced alkylate the solvent (toluene). Both of these reports only speculate on what actually catalyzes the Friedel–Crafts reaction. Our report on bis(pyrazolylmethyl)benzenenickel and EtAlCl2 catalyst systems [21c] however, gives a more extensive analysis of the product mix which shows that the nickel and aluminum act as a tandem catalyst for the oligomerization and Friedel–Crafts alkylation reactions to occur; although the alkylation is not selective. In the present work, we have used new pyrazolyl nickel complexes as pre-catalysts for ethylene reactions, with various aluminum co-catalysts and different solvents. It is clear that products with these new pre-catalyst are co-catalyst and solvent dependent; and also represent the first pre-catalyst, co-catalyst and toluene combination that selectively produces butyl-, di-butyl- and tri-butyl toluenes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and general instrumentations Ligands and complexes were synthesized using standard Schlenk techniques. All solvents used were of analytical grade, but were dried and distilled prior to use. Methanol was dried and distilled from CaH2, dichloromethane from P2O5; while tetrahydrofuran was dried over Na and benzophenone. Sodium borohydride and [NiBr2(DME)] were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and were used as received; while alkylpyrazolylamine [22], 2-(3,5-dimethyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl]-pyridin-2-ylmethylene-imine (L1) [23], 2-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl]-pyridin-2-ylmethylene-imine (L2) [23], were synthesized according to literature procedure. Spectroscopic data on ligands and metal complexes were obtained using a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR equipped with a diamond ATR and a Bruker Ultrashield 400 (400MHz for 1H and 100MHz for 13C{1H} in CDCl3). The chemical shifts are reported in δ (ppm) and referenced to the residual proton and carbon signals 7.24 and 77.0ppm respectively of CDCl3 the NMR solvent. NMR spectroscopy data for polyethylene were recorded on a JEOL JNM-ECS 400, which has 1H at 400MHz 1H and 100MHz for 13C{1H} with digital resolution of 0.11 and 0.96Hz, respectively. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario elementar III microcube CHNS analyzer at Rhodes University (South Africa). The Analytical Services Unit at the University of Stellenbosch (South Africa) run the ESI-MS spectra on a Waters API Qualtro micro spectrophotometer. GC analyses were performed on a Varian 3900 with 15mm×0.25mm dimethylpolysiloxane column at initial temperature of 40°C and then ramped to 300°C at 5°Cmin−1. GC–MS analyses were performed on a Shimadzu GC–MS-QP2010 fitted with a quadrupole mass detector. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed on a Seiko DSC 7020 analyzer at a heating and cooling rate of 10°Cmin−1. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a Seiko EXSTAR 6000 TG/DTA 6200 analyzer at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. GPC analyses were carried out on a GL Sciences instrument (model PU 610 high-performance-liquid-chromatography pump, CO 631 a liquid chromatography column oven, and RI 713 refractive-index detector) and with two columns (Shodex KF-804L) at 148°C and with polystyrene as internal standard. The columns were eluted with 1,2-dichlorobenzene at 1mLmin−1. Samples (10mg/mL) for GPC were dissolved at 135°C in 1,2-chlorobenzene for 30min before introducing them to an auto-sampler set at 148°C for data collection. 2.2 Syntheses of ligands 2.2.1 Synthesis of 2-(3,5-dimethyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl-(1H-pyrrol-2-ylmethylene)-imine (L3) A solution of pyrrole-2-carboxaldehyde (0.39g, 4.00mmol) and 3,5-dimethylpyrazolylamine (0.57g, 4.00mmol) in ethanol (50mL) was heated at reflux for 12h. After filtration, the filtrate was evaporated to afford a sticky dark orange residue. The residue was re-dissolved in CH2Cl2 and filtered to remove insoluble material. The resultant filtrate was evaporated and the crude product sublimed to remove unreacted amine and aldehyde to afford pure L3 as a dark orange oily material. Complexes 2–4 were prepared following the procedure as described for the preparation of complex 1, using the appropriate reagents. 2.3.2 Synthesis of [2-{(3,5-di-tert-butyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridin-2-yl}methyl-ethan-amine nickel(II) bromide] (2) Complex 2 was prepared from L2a (0.10g, 0.32mmol) and [NiBr2(DME)] (0.01g 0.32mmol) and isolated as a green solid. Yield=0.14g (81%). Anal. Calcd for C19H30Br2N4Ni: C, 42.82; H, 5.67; N, 10.51. Found: C, 43.21; H, 6.10; N, 11.01. ESI-MS+ m/z (%)=[M]+ =530.02 (50%). 2.3.3 Synthesis of [2-{(3,5-dimethyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl(1H-pyrrol-2-yl}methyl-amine nickel(II) bromide] (3) Complex 3 was prepared from L3a (0.13g, 0.59mmol) and [NiBr2(DME)] (0.19g 0.58mmol) and isolated as a violet solid. Yield=0.20g (80%). IR (Diamond ATR, cm−1): 3379 υ(NH). Anal. Calcd for C12H18Br2N4Ni: C, 33.00; H, 4.15; N, 12.52. Found: C, 33.18; H, 4.36; N, 12.52. ESI-MS+ m/z (%)=[M+K−H]+ =471.3 (100%). 2.3.4 Synthesis of [2-{(3,5-di-tert-butyl-pyrazol-1-yl)ethyl-1H-pyrrol-2-yl}methyl-amine nickel(II) bromide] (4) Complex 4 was prepared from L4a (0.12g, 0.39mmol) and [NiBr2(DME)] (0.12g 0.39mmol) and product was isolated as a light violet solid. Yield=0.15g (75%). IR (Diamond ATR, cm−1): 3277 υ(NH). Anal. Calcd for C18H30Br2N4Ni: C, 41.50; H, 5.80; N, 10.75. Found: C, 42.00; H, 5.45; N, 11.33. ESI-MS+ m/z (%)=[M]+ =520.96 (50%). 2.4 Molecular structure determination by single crystal X-ray analysis Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 2.2CHCl 3 and 3 were collected on a Bruker APEXII diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation and diffractometer to crystal distance of 4.00cm. The initial cell matrix was obtained from three series of scans at different starting angles. Each series consisted of 12 frames collected at intervals of 0.5° in a 6° range about with an exposure time of 10 s per frame. The reflections were successfully indexed by an automated indexing routine built in the APEXII program suite. The data were collected using the full sphere data collection routine to survey the reciprocal space to the extent of a full sphere to a resolution of 0.75Å. Data were harvested by collecting 2982 frames at intervals of 0.5° scans in ω and φ with exposure times of 10s per frame [24]. A successful solution by the direct methods of SHELXS97 provided all non-hydrogen atoms from the E-map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the neighboring atoms with relative isotropic displacement coefficients [25]. 2.5 Catalysis 2.5.1 General procedure for ethylene oligomerization reactions A 500mL steel autoclave was heated under vacuum for 2h at 160°C and subsequently allowed to cool to the temperature required for the oligomerization reaction. Toluene solution of the catalyst precursor used for each reaction was first introduced into the reactor and the reaction mixture saturated with ethylene at 1bar. This was stirred for 10min and ethylene vented off. Ethylaluminum dichloride (EtAlCl2), in toluene, was added to the reaction mixture via a cannula and the reactor pressurized with ethylene to the required pressure and the maintained at this pressure throughout the reaction. After setting the reaction temperature, the reaction was run for the required time, after which the ethylene feed was turned off. To ensure that volatile products were not lost, the reactor was vented while connected to two liquid nitrogen cooled traps. Once the venting was completed the reaction was quenched with 10% HCl in methanol, and the product sampled for GC and GC–MS analyses. Evaporation of solvent from the reaction mixture allowed the product to be isolated. 2.5.2 General procedure for ethylene polymerization To a 50mL of stainless autoclave containing the appropriate catalyst (0.01mmol) and MAO was added 20mL of toluene. The autoclave was filled with ethylene to the required pressure and placed on an Eyela chem-station for the required time and temperature. After the prescribed polymerization time and ethylene pressure, the reactor was vented and reaction worked up to afford solid polyethylene. The microstructure of the polymer was determined using the 1H (Figure S10) and 13C{1H} NMR spectra (Figure S9) run in 1,1,2,2 tertrachloroethane-d 2 as solvent at 120°C. 2.5.3 General characterization of oligomers Oligomerization products were characterized using GC, GC–MS and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The GC and GC–MS instruments were calibrated with standard samples, which were used to establish the retention times for various authentic oligomer (C6–C20) compositions. The oligomer components in the oligomerization reactions were established by comparing the retention times of products of the oligomerization runs to that of standard samples. This helped in establishing the identity of the oligomer products. GC–MS analysis was used to identify the Friedel–Crafts alkylated products. The mass of the products was determined by difference in mass of 70.0mL of toluene (60.9g) or chlorobenzene (77.5g) and mass of final liquid at the end of each reaction. 2.5.4 General characterization of polyethylene Polyethylene was characterized by 1H and 13C{1H} NMR, DSC, TGA and high temperature GPC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Syntheses of ligands and complexes Compounds L3 and L4 were synthesized via the condensation of the appropriate reagents and were obtained as oils; while compounds L1a–L4a were prepared by reducing the imine bonds in L1–L4 with 5 equivalents of NaBH4 (Schemes 1 and 2 ). The 1H NMR spectra of L3 and L4 showed all the characteristic peaks for these types of compounds. For example, the imine peaks for L3 was observed at 7.77ppm, CH2 linker protons peaks were observed as two triples at 3.89 and 4.20ppm and pyrrole protons signals between 6.20 and 6.84ppm. IR spectroscopy data confirmed the presence of an imine functional group in L3 and L4 at 1634 and 1647cm−1, respectively. Similarly the 1H NMR spectra of compounds L1a–L4a showed all the characteristic peaks of the corresponding imine compounds [23] including new singlets for CH2 protons at 3.89ppm for L1a, at 3.90ppm for L2a, at 3.76ppm for L3a and at 3.92ppm for L4a indicative of the successful reduction of the imine functionality in L1–L4 to an amine. Indeed IR stretching frequencies between 3213 and 3298cm−1 for L1a–L4a were indicative of the formation of secondary amines; while high resolution mass spectrometry of L3, L4 and L1a–L4a produced molecular ions at 217.1457 (100%), 301.2395 (100%), 231.1621 (100%), 315.2549 (100%), 219.1501 (100%) and 300.2544 (100%) respectively and elemental analysis confirmed the purity of these compounds. Reactions of L1–L4 in CH2Cl2 with [NiBr2(DME)] resulted in the hydrolysis of these ligands to give pyrazolylamine nickel(II) dihalide complexes, similar to what we recently reported for other pyrazolylimine nickel(II) dihalide reactions [20]. We therefore reduced the imine ligand to the amine analogs, followed by their complexation of [NiBr2(DME)] with the amine ligands L1a–L4a. These reactions led to the isolation of complexes 1–4 (Schemes 1 and 2). Complexes 1–4 were obtained as analytically pure solids in high yields (75–81%). While complexes 1 and 2 are green solids, 3 and 4 are violet and light violet solids respectively. Complexes 1 and 2 are hydroscopic and were stored under nitrogen, but 3 and 4 are air stable and so were stored without special precaution. Further analysis by mass spectrometry gave molecular ion peaks at m/z =445.93 (1), 530.02 (2) and 520.96 (3). However, complex 4 gave m/z =471.30 (100%), which is assigned to a molecular ion with one less hydrogen plus potassium. From the IR spectroscopic data all the nickel complexes showed sharp secondary amine peaks between 3317 and 3356cm−1; these show significant shifts toward higher frequencies compared to secondary amine peaks of corresponding ligands. 3.2 Molecular structures 2.2CHCl 3 and 3 Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis of 2.2CHCl 3 and 3 were obtained by slow evaporation of their CH2Cl2 or CHCl3 solutions at 25°C. Crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters are given in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Selected bond lengths and bond angles of these complexes are listed in the captions for figures. Complex 2 (Fig. 1 ) crystallizes with two molecules of CHCl3, while complex 3 (Fig. 2 ) crystallized with no solvent. The nickel centers of complexes 2.2CHCl 3 and 3 showed penta- and tetra-coordinate geometry respectively. The geometry of 2.2CHCl 3 is a pseudo octahedral arrangement and this is due to agostic interaction between the hydrogen atom on C15 and Ni metal, while 3 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The bond lengths of NiN(pz) 2.0031(15)Å, and NiN(py) 2.0096(15)Å for 2.2CHCl 3 and NiN(pz) 1.9756(15)Å for 3 are shorter than what is reported for similar complexes [26]. However, the NiBr bond length for 2.2CHCl 3 is longer than 3, although both are within statistical range for similar bonds [27]. 3.3 Ethylene oligomerization reactions of complex 1–4 activated with EtAlCl2 Pre-catalysts 1–4 were screened for their abilities to catalyze ethylene oligomerization or polymerization reactions using EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst. With this co-catalyst, all the complexes were active as ethylene oligomerization catalysts. The oligomerization reactions were found to be moderately exothermic, with maximum temperatures ranging between 40 and 60°C from an initial set reactor temperature of 30°C. However, after 30min the temperature stabilized at 30°C similar to the observed conditions for similar pyrazolylnickel catalysts [19,21c]. Interestingly, when the solvent was changed from toluene to chlorobenzene a very exothermic reaction was observed; with temperatures rising to between 100 and 110°C in chlorobenezene. The more exothermic nature of the reaction could be due to higher solubility of pre-catalysts in chlorobenzene than in toluene and hence the much higher initial rate of conversion of monomer to products in chlorobenzene. Pre-catalysts 1–4 showed significant activities toward ethylene oligomerization; producing butene (C4), hexene (C6) and alkylated toluenes (Scheme 3 ). The identities of these products were established by a combination of GC, GC–MS and by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S1 (supporting information), GC (Fig. 3 ), and GC–MS (Figures S2–S6 (supporting information)). By spiking the samples with authentic 1-hexene we were able to confirm the hexene in the product mix 1-hexene. We did not have 1-butene standard to spike the butene peak in the GC chromatogram, but the single peak in the GC chromatogram strongly suggested the product is 1-butene. The GC and GC–MS data showed that the alkylated species were all butyl-toluenes. The peaks with retention times between 13.0 and 13.8min were identified as isomers of monobutyl-toluene (A). These are isomers with the butyl groups in ortho and para positions of the toluene and with butyl groups that are both linear and branched. This explains why there are three isomers of this product. Retention times between 16.8 and 17.8min in the chromatogram are peaks of dibutyl-toluene isomers (B), with isomers that have linear and branched butyl groups in ortho and para positions of the toluene. Lastly, the peak in the chromatogram with retention time19.6min is assigned to tributyl-toluene (C) and has no isomers. There was no evidence of alkylation of toluene by hexene, in contrast to hexene alkylation reported by us [21c] and others [21a]. These nickel catalysts (1–4) are unique because unlike other nickel catalysts [19–21], they are highly selective in alkylating toluene. All previous nickel catalysts [19–21] produced a mixture of butyl-, and hexyl-toluenes. It is therefore clear that the ligands in 1–4 are responsible for the selectivity we observe in the toluene alkylation products with complexes 1–4. Reaction parameters such as reaction time, solvent and ethylene pressure were investigated. However, the effect of temperature was not considered due to the exothermic nature of the reactions. Tables 1 and 2 show the results of this investigation. The activities of 1–4 were 800, 1200, 2400 and 1000kgmol−1 Nih−1 respectively when the reactions were run for 30min with these catalysts (Table 1, entries 1, 3, 9 and 16). Activities for 1 and 4 decreased to 600 and 1000kgmol−1 h−1 respectively when reaction time was increased to 60min (Table 1, entries 2 and 17) while activities for 2 and 3 increased to 1500 and 3000kgmol−1 Nih−1 respectively (Table 1, entries 5 and 11). At reaction time 3h, however, the activities of 2 and 3 significantly dropped to 1250 and 1500kgmol−1 h−1, respectively. The decrease in activities is most likely due to catalyst deactivation. Time also influenced product distribution. Longer reaction times resulted in higher combined percent composition of compounds A, B, and C in the product mixture. For instance, using 2 and increasing reaction time from 30 to 120min the composition of A, B and C in the product mixture increased from 77% to 88% (Table 1, entries 3–6). This suggests increase in production of butene with time and is manifest in the amount of butyl-toluenes formed. Brookhart [28] and Small [29] have reported increased formation of higher olefin oligomers composition in reaction product with time, and attribute this to olefin reincorporation. We did not observe formation of higher olefin oligomers beyond hexene and hence no olefin reincorporation. Increase in ethylene pressure also significantly increased the activities of both catalyst 2 and 3 (Table 1, entries 5, 7, 8, 11, 14 and 15). For instance, a threefold increase in pressure from 10 to 30bar increased the activity of 2 from 1500 to 4000kgmol−1 Nih−1 (Table 1, entries 5 and 8); while the activity of 3 increased from 3000 to 12,500kgmol−1 Nih−1 (Table 1, entries 11 and 15). Similar increases are known in ethylene oligomerization and polymerization reactions [28,29]. Catalyst 3 was the most active among the four nickel complexes for the oligomerization of ethylene. However, compared to other pyrazolyl nickel ethylene oligomerization catalysts like ([{2-(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1yl)ethylamino}NiBr2] [14], [{2,6-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-ylmethyl)pyridine}NiBr2] [19] and [{2,6-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene}-NiBr2] [21c]), the activities of 1–4 are lower; but it is the high selectivity for the formation of butyltoluenes that makes 3 and the other complexes in this report unique. From the experiments in toluene, pre-catalysts 2 and 3 were found to be the most active and thus were used for the rest of the ethylene experiments. When the ethylene reaction was run in chlorobenzene, catalysts 2 and 3 produced butene, hexene and branched polyethylene (Scheme 4 ). GC data showed that in chlorobenzene trimerization of ethylene was the dominant oligomerization product (Figure S7, Supporting Information). When the chlorobenzene was evaporated at the end of each reaction, oily materials were obtained and identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy to be highly branched polyethylene (Figure S8, supporting information). Merna and coworkers [30] have reported the formation of branched polyethylene in similar reactions. The degree of branching of the polyethylene produces by pre-catalysts 1–4 was calculated using the formula (2/3×(CH3/CH2·CH)×1000) [30b], and found to be rather high, with as branches as high 660 branches per 1000 carbon. There was no evidence of alkylation of chlorobenzene by either butene or hexene from either the GC or 1H NMR data. This is not surprising as deactivated benzene rings do not readily undergo Friedel–Crafts alkylation [31]. 3.4 Ethylene polymerization reactions with 2 and 3 When complexes 2 and 3 were activated with MAO and the ethylene reaction run in toluene, we observed the formation of high density polyethylene (HDPE) (Scheme 5 ). Since catalyst performance is largely dependent on polymerization conditions, we investigated variations in Al:Ni ratios, reaction time, temperature and pressure on ethylene polymerization using pre-catalysts 2 and 3 (Table 3 ). Al:Ni ratio of 1600:1 was found to be optimum (Table 3, entry 17); above this ratio activity and molecular weights decreased dramatically, although the highest molecular weight (447,300) was found at Al:Ni ratio of 1200:1 (Table 3 entry 9). Increase in temperature from 30°C through to 60°C resulted in a gradual increase in activity and molecular weight of polymer but with no change in the morphology. However, temperatures above 60°C activity and molecular weight decreased (Table 3, entry 14), suggesting that chain growth termination is more rapid at this temperature [32]. For both catalysts increase in ethylene pressure and reaction time resulted in increased activity and polymer molecular weight, something that is generally expected for change in pressure [33]. The DSC thermograms of the polyethylenes had very sharp T m that ranged from 132.8 to 135.5°C; characteristic of highly linear and crystalline polyethylene [34]. The 1H NMR and 13C{1H} NMR spectra of the polyethylenes in 1,1,2,2 tertrachloroethane-d 2 at 120°C, showed only one strong peak at 1.34 and 29.4ppm in the 1H NMR and 13C{1H} spectra respectively (Figure S9 and S10, supporting information). These are further evidence of the high linearity of the polyethylene. The monomodal nature of the high temperature GPC results also suggests that the catalysts for the polymerization are single-site catalysts (Figure S11, supporting information). 4 Conclusions The four pyrazolylamine nickel complexes (1–4) investigated for their activities for ethylene oligomerization and polymerization reactions showed strong dependence on co-catalysts and solvents. With EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst and toluene as solvent, all four nickel complexes oligomerized ethylene to butene and hexene; and selectively had the butene alkylate the toluene to butyltoluene, dibutyltoluene and tributyltoluene. In chlorobenzene and EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst, the nickel complexes 2 and 3 catalyzed ethylene oligomerization to butene and hexene, and but also produced branched polyethylene. Changing the co-catalyst to MAO for these two nickel complexes and running the reaction in toluene produced HDPE. These results demonstrate the roles solvents and co-catalysts play in the ethylene oligomerization and polymerization reactions with these nickel complexes. coredata.dc:description: The pyrazolylamine ligands, 2-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethan-amine (L1a), 2-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethan-amine (L2a), 2-(3,5-dimethyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl-(1H-pyrrol-2-ylmethyl)-amine (L3a), 2-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-pyrazol-1-yl)-ethyl-(1H-pyrrol-2-ylmethyl)-amine (L4a), were prepared by reducing the corresponding imine compounds L1–L4. L1a–L4a were then reacted with [NiBr2(DME)] to form the nickel complexes, [NiBr2(L1a)] (1), [NiBr2(L2a)] (2), [NiBr2(L3a)] (3) and [NiBr2(L4a)] (4) in high yields. When activated with aluminum co-catalysts, all four nickel complexes were able to catalyze the oligomerization or polymerization of ethylene; but the products of these reactions were co-catalyst and solvent dependent. With EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst and in toluene, butene and hexene were formed, which subsequently alkylated the solvent selectively to butyl-, dibutyl- and tri-butyltoluene. The same catalysts in chlorobenzene produced butene, hexene and highly branched polyethylene. Changing the co-catalysts to MAO and with toluene as solvent, complexes 2 and 3 catalyzed the polymerization of ethylene to high molecular weight (447,300Da) linear high density polyethylene (ca T m =135.5°C); with polydispersity indices ranging from 1.63 to 2.51.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent and co-catalyst dependent pyrazolylpyridinamine and pyrazolylpyrroleamine nickel(II) catalyzed oligomerization and polymerization of ethylene
